questions.question_text: Which destination UDP port is used by WAN Edge router to make a DTLS connection with vBond Orchestrator?

discussion.content: ANswer "C" is correct. Destination UDP port 12346 is used by WAN Edge router to make a DTLS connection with vBond Orchestrator.

Selected Answer: B
Alert is not belong to Events section but syslog, IDS/IPS, URL filtering etc.
See page 313 in https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/vManage-Help/vmanage-help-18-4.pdf

Selected Answer: B
Question states Severity Level for events, under Events filter, severity there are only 3 options, hence Critical - B is the correct answer
a.Critical—indicates that action needs to be taken immediately.
b.Major—indicates that the problem needs immediate attention from you but, is not critical enough to bring down the network.
c.Minor—is informational only. 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/Monitor-And-Maintain/monitor-maintain-book/m-alarms-events-logs.html

B is correct
because critical is include a events category in vmanage and need be taken immediately action but other options are syslog priority in vmanage

"In the Severity drop-down, select the event severity level. Events generated by Cisco SD-WAN devices are collected by vManage NMS and classified as:
Critical—indicates that action needs to be taken immediately.
Major—indicates that the problem needs to be looked into but is not critical enough to bring down the network.
Minor—is informational only."

source(search 'Set Event Filters'): https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/vManage-Help/xe-17-vedge-20/b-vmanage-help/m-help-monitor.html#c_Events_12335.xml

Answer is D alert

Select the severity of the syslog message to save. The severity indicates the seriousness of the event that generated the
message. priority can be one of the following:
• Emergency—System is unusable (corresponds to syslog severity 0).
• Alert— Action must be taken immediately (corresponds to syslog severity 1).
• Critical—Critical: A serious condition (corresponds to syslog severity 2).
• Error—An error condition that does not fully impair system usability (corresponds to syslog severity 3).
• Warning—A minor error condition (corresponds to syslog severity 4).
• Notice—A normal, but significant condition (corresponds to syslog severity 5).
• Informational—Routine condition (the default) (corresponds to syslog severity 6).

https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/vManage-Help/vmanage-help-18-4.pdf

Selected Answer: B

Major – indicates that the problem needs to be looked into but is not critical enough to bring down the network.
Minor – is informational only.

questions.question_text: An administrator is configuring the severity level on the vManage NMS for events that indicate that an action must be taken immediately. Which severity level must be configured?

discussion.content: They are asking about "which policy", so it should be C -> Traffic Policy.

comments.content: It should be D - localized policy - because it is only for PARIS site vEdge

Localized Policy does not care about applications when it comes to TLOCs. 
https://www.networkacademy.io/ccie-enterprise/sdwan/what-is-a-localized-policy

discussion.content: Option A. We have this configured for DIA Teams traffic, I have just confirmed this.
Correct is A - TLOC is centralized Policy +LIST

It is Application Aware Routing Policy. In order to create App-Aware Routing we need to create Lists and there define specific apps.
If you go Configuration > Policies > Centralized Policy > Add Policy > you will see Application list (in the Create Groups of Interest page).
But if you go Configuration > Policies > Localized Policy > Add Policy > there's no Application list at least. I verified both in vManage version 20.9.4.1.
Option C is also wrong, because first you need to define lists for App-Aware Policy.
Option A is correct.
It is Centralized Policy, thus, >> C

C.
Localised Policy > Lists

Option C

The question is taken straight out of the Cisco guide.

The automate procedure looks at defining the DNS server on VPN 0 via VManage SSH console
config terminal
vpn 0
dns 208.67.222.222 primary
commit and-quit

Insure that NETCONF and SSH are allowed on the controller VPN 0 interface
config terminal
 interface ge0/0
 tunnel-interface
 allow-service sshd
 allow-service netconf
commit and-quit

Selected Answer: C
Automated certificate signing through Cisco Systems
With this option, certificate signing requests are automatically sent to the Cisco PnP cloud service where the certificate is
signed. The vManage then automatically retrieves the certificate and installs it. A DNS server needs to be configured to
resolve the hostname, cloudsso.cisco.com and subsequently, apx.cisco.com. The vManage needs to reach both servers on
TCP port 443.
Note that this option requires vManage version 19.1 or higher (19.2 or higher is recommended) and also requires that Smart
Account credentials are configured before this certificate option can be configured.
Procedure 1: Verify Cisco server reachability
1. Ensure that a DNS server is defined for VPN 0 on vManage via SSH or console:
config terminal
vpn 0
dns 208.67.222.222 primary
commit and-quit

questions.question_text: An engineer must automate certificate signing through Cisco. Which vManage configuration achieves this task?

choices.C: vpn 0 dns 208.67.222.222 primary allow-service dns allow-service sshd allow-service netconf
choices.A: vpn 0 allow-service dns allow-service sshd allow-service netconf
choices.B: vpn 512 dns 208.67.222.222 primary allow-service dns allow-service sshd allow-service netconf
choices.D: vpn 512 allow-service dns allow-service sshd allow-service netconf

discussion.content: correct answer is C
correct is D

comments.content: when writing vice-versa (typo) I meant bidirectionally.
It also says, users in VPN91 must reach to users in VPN92 not vice-versa.

discussion.content: A does exactly what is asked. The question doesn't say that 10 to the 9Xs is two-way. It says users in VPN10 should reach the 9Xs. So, the 9X routes should leak to 10, and not vice versa. Option A does this, plus it leaks the 9Xs to each other, as required.
it must be C
Answer is C
